UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS • DIVISION OF COMMUNICATIONS • URBANA
Office of the Dean
Messrs, Seymour N. Siegels August 6, 1952
Graydon Ausinus
Frank E. Schooley
Burton Paulu
Parker Wheatley CONFIDENTIAL
Alvin Gaines
Waldo Abbot
Richard B. Hull
John Dunn
Allen Miller
Gentlemen:
I hope you will forgive me for communicating with the whole NAEB
board, I am doing it to save as much time as possible. Time is of the
essence, for Jim Miles* president insists that Jim come back to Purdue by
November 15.
This is a body blow, because it comes awfully late in the summer,
after many persons have made firm plans for the fall, and also because it
comes at an extremely bad time for our relations with the Kellogg Foundation.
I*m sure I don*t have to tell you that the Foundation was very much worried
after our board meeting at Battle Creek, and when Jim and I were summoned up
there to present the formal report and request for the second year we got a
severe grilling. I don*t like to have these delicate relations further
strained by a change in directors.
It does no good to say that it would have helped if President
Hovde had told Jim this last April, when he assured Jim a second year*s leave.
The point is, it has happened, and we have to repair the damage as best we can.
As I see it,
(1) We*ve got to move fast. We can’t afford now, as we did before,
to spend several months looking for a director. Especially if we get an
academic person, we have to get him before the academic year starts. Whoever
we get, we have to get him in here, or on a Ford fellowship, for a month or
two before Jim leaves, so he catches on to what happens in this operation.
(2) We’ve got to get a man for the next four years — if we want to
keep Kellogg interested. Kellogg is extremely allergic to changes in directors
If we propose a new director for one year, I think we’ll lose our grant. On
the other hand, if we tell Masters that we have to face the loss of Jim some¬
time anyway, and by changing now we can get continuity — supposing, of course,
the new man works out all right — for the rest of the project time, then we
have a pretty good case.
(3) When we know our man, we have to present this matter very care¬
fully to the Kellogg people. I’ll try to guide you from my experience with
them, but please don’t throw me to the dogs as you did last May in Battle Creek
